citations.narrative:
*There are 2 servals housed in an enclosure, where the barrier between the animals and the public does not extend to
completely cover the enclosure. The barrier is lacking in one corner. There was also a door/gate in the barrier that was
broken.
*There are 2 lynxes housed in an enclosure, where the barrier between the animals and the public does not extend to
completely cover the enclosure. The barrier is lacking in one corner.
Insufficient distance and/or barriers between animals and the public may result in unauthorized contact between animals
and members of the public. This contact can result in stress, disease transmission, injuries or even death to animals
and/or visitors.
Animals must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animals and to the public, with sufficient distance and/or
barriers between the animals and the general viewing public as to assure the safety of animals and the public.
Public barriers to both serval and lynx enclosures as well as the broken door/gate to the serval enclosure were corrected
at the time of inspection on 1/31/2024.

A Blue and Gold Macaw was being temporarily housed for veterinary care/observation in the Chapel Building. A
supplemental heat lamp was plugged in and its cord was running along the side and across the top of the cage. The
macaw could easily reach the cord and if bitten could result in electrocution.
The primary enclosure must protect birds from injury.
The supplemental heat source was unplugged and removed during the inspection on 1/31/2024 in preparation for
relocating the macaw back to its normal enclosure.

On November 22, 2023, a Red-legged Seriema (“Sigma”) was found outside its enclosure, from which it had escaped. It
was found with a laceration on the right wing and left leg. The Attending Veterinarian was called and noted the bird to be
non-responsive upon initial examination. The bird was treated aggressively over a 2-day period but ultimately died.
Primary enclosures must be designed and constructed so that they contain the birds securely. Failure to do so could
result in escape, injury, and/or death of the animal.
Correct by February 15th, 2024, by ensuring that all animal enclosures are structurally sound, maintained in good repair,
and contain the animals securely.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
HARVEY KENT, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Repeat
   
Handling of animals. 
*There are 2 servals housed in an enclosure, where the barrier between the animals and the public does not extend to 
completely cover the enclosure. The barrier is lacking in one corner. There was also a door/gate in the barrier that was 
broken.  
*There are 2 lynxes housed in an enclosure, where the barrier between the animals and the public does not extend to 
completely cover the enclosure. The barrier is lacking in one corner.  
Insufficient distance and/or barriers between animals and the public may result in unauthorized contact between animals 
and members of the public. This contact can result in stress, disease transmission, injuries or even death to animals 
and/or visitors.  
 
Animals must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animals and to the public, with sufficient distance and/or 
barriers between the animals and the general viewing public as to assure the safety of animals and the public.  
 
Public barriers to both serval and lynx enclosures as well as the broken door/gate to the serval enclosure were corrected 
at the time of inspection on 1/31/2024. 
3.153(a)(1)(ii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
A Blue and Gold Macaw was being temporarily housed for veterinary care/observation in the Chapel Building. A 
supplemental heat lamp was plugged in and its cord was running along the side and across the top of the cage. The 
macaw could easily reach the cord and if bitten could result in electrocution.  
 
The primary enclosure must protect birds from injury. 
 
The supplemental heat source was unplugged and removed during the inspection on 1/31/2024 in preparation for 
relocating the macaw back to its normal enclosure. 
3.153(a)(1)(iii)  Critical

Primary enclosures. 
On November 22, 2023, a Red-legged Seriema (“Sigma”) was found outside its enclosure, from which it had escaped. It 
was found with a laceration on the right wing and left leg. The Attending Veterinarian was called and noted the bird to be 
non-responsive upon initial examination. The bird was treated aggressively over a 2-day period but ultimately died.  
 
Primary enclosures must be designed and constructed so that they contain the birds securely. Failure to do so could 
result in escape, injury, and/or death of the animal. 
 
Correct by February 15th, 2024, by ensuring that all animal enclosures are structurally sound, maintained in good repair, 
and contain the animals securely. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
HARVEY KENT, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
